column4: i've just installed an ubuntu 8.04 amd64, and there is no kernel installed, nothing in /boot; how can i fix this?
ehh.. and you're running it now? without a kernel?
the live cd, of course
phew.. it was getting spooky there for a minute =).. I would try a reinstall.. don't know if you can just download the kernel and install it manually without the system running
and what would that change if i reinstall it?
hopefully whatever happened when you installed it the first time won't happen again.. if the same thing happens again I would start checking the cd for defects, perhaps download a new iso and so on
i reinstalled the system, but nothing changed
have you checked the cd for errors? there is an option to do that when it boots up
well.. I can't really think of any reason for the installer to skip the kernels..
the simlinks in / are also created, but they point to no existing file
an interesting thing: when i restarted the installer, the partitioning program said that 64M is used on /boot, although there is nothing in that directory
you've done a fsck on that partition?
it's a brand new disk, i bought it this afternoon, some hours ago
I didn't mean for the hard drive.. I meant if the file system had been messed up in the install process.. or you've formatted it during the install?
yes i did format it
but i think i just fooled you and myself...
ok =).. what was it?
because the files are there, i did not mount the boot partition; still, grub does not find the files
ahhh... then we need to find out why grub doesn't find it.. at least I like this problem better =)
sorry for that, and thanks for coming with me this far with my folly...
no worries, happy to do it
i justed had to swap hd0 and hd1, thanks a lot for your persevering help
ah.. I've been reading up on how grub does it's magic.. interesting stuff.. you're welcome
